metadata.title: Journal Pre-proof Urticarial exanthem as early diagnostic clue for COVID-19 infection Title: Urticarial exanthem as early diagnostic clue for COVID-19 infection

body_text.text: During the COVID-19 epidemic, dermatologists and other physicians are treating patients with cutaneous manifestations related to this infection. Due to the high risk of taking photographs of these patients, there are few clinical images reported in the literature. We would like to share an interesting case of COVID-19 infection.

A 61-year-old Spanish Medical Doctor (M.D.) came to the Emergency Department with a 4-days history of a progressive cutaneous rash. He was treating patients with coronavirus infection for three weeks. On presentation, his temperature was 37,3ºC. He did not complain of respiratory symptoms (as cough or dyspnea), headache, malaise, sore throat or nasal congestion. The patient also denied taking any drugs during the last two months.
Physical examination showed an urticarial rash consisting of confluent, edematous and erythematous papules on his thighs, arms, and forearms ( fig 1A and 1B) .

Palms and soles were spared. Cutaneous lesions were mildly itchy. COVID-19 infection was suspected due to the current epidemiologic situation. A nasopharyngeal sample was obtained and a reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) confirmed the diagnosis of COVID-19 infection. Other common viral infections such as parvovirus B19, rubella, measles, Epstein-Barr, human herpes virus 6 (HHV-6) and enterovirus that might cause fever and rash were ruled out by laboratory investigation. A chest X-Ray did not reveal lung abnormalities. As the patient had no risk factor and following the Spanish Guidelines, he did not receive any specific treatment for the infection. The patient remained afebrile during the next week. Cutaneous rash solved in 7 days. The patient just received oral antihistamine due to mild pruritus. The key aspect in this COVID-19 epidemic is to prevent transmission. This may pose a challenge in asymptomatic patients and in those with atypical symptoms. All professionals should recognize the possibility that a patient might have only a skin rash and think of this disease to promptly prevent transmission.

FIGREF0.text: Like other types of RNA viruses, COVID-19 infection can present with cutaneous findings. There are only two reports of cutaneous manifestations with COVID-19 disease 1-3 . However, none of them reported clinical images due to the high risk of infection by introducing a photographic device in the patients' rooms. COVID-19 infection can present with cutaneous findings. Some of these patients are afebrile and developed cutaneous manifestations at the onset, without any other symptoms
